column4: I added modes "1280x1024" to my xorg.conf, but I still can only select 640x480 in displays. How can I force higher resolution? (there's no resolutions listed under "Monitor" should there be?)
xrandr lists 640x480 and 320x240
Quadro 4600
..or maybe 4700
It worked fine on another 1920x1200 monitor, but this one is connected with a 15pin d-sub
NVIDIA Corporation G80 [Quadro FX 4600] (rev a2)
so I guess there's no data communication
If you are using the nvidia proprietary driver, you'll need to use the "Nvidia X Server Settings" application
Check "/var/log/Xorg.0.log" see if the driver is getting a valid EDID from the monitor?
In the "Screen" section - in the "Monitor" section you put the Horizontal/Vertical refresh frequencies
Check, that's there. Looks resonable
The frequencies allow the driver to check that that the monitor can accept any modes that are selected
There are webpages that can generate the correct modes for the Screen section of xorg.conf if you give them the frequency-range of the monitor.
But first, I'd suggest you search for that monitor's correct frequency range!
I'd expect to be seeing something like "HorizSync 30.000-81.00"
With the range you reported, it would only be able to do 800x600 max I'd guess

I'm not sure off top of my head, but as I said, there are web-pages that can generate this stuff for you. Give them frequencies, they give you modes. Give them modes (or max resolutions) and they'll give you frequencies
It works now. Changing  HorizSync to 30.000-81.00 and everything works as expected. Thanks :)
What group owns that device node ("ls -l /dev/ttyUSB0") ?
Usually, you'd add the user that needs to access the USB serial port to the group that owns the device node
Often it's the "dialup" group
sorry, "dialout" group
sudo adduser $USER dailout ... you'll need to log-out and log-in for the new group to take effect though
oops, typo! "sudo adduser $USER dialout" !!
